question: What were the occupations of the person who contributed a track to a 2005 hip-hop album co-produced with Marc Predka?
gold_answer: professional wrestler, actor, and hip hop musician
llm_answer: The context does not specify the occupations of the person who contributed a track to the 2005 hip-hop album *You Can't See Me*, which was co-produced with Marc Predka.

context.text: Marc Joseph Predka (born April 21, 1975), better known by his stage name Trademarc (formerly Tha Trademarc ), is an American rapper. He first came to prominence when he and his younger first cousin, WWE wrestler John Cena , collaborated on the 2005 album You Can't See Me , including Cena's entrance theme " The Time Is Now ". He also appeared in the music videos of the songs, "Bad Bad Man" and "Right Now" with Cena. Prior to the album, Trademarc appeared on Cena's first WWE DVD Word Life . In August 2007, Trademarc appeared at Total Nonstop Action Wrestling 's (TNA) Hard Justice pay-per-view as the "new boyfriend" of Karen Angle , later revealed to be a ruse when Karen and Trademarc helped Karen's "estranged" husband Kurt Angle win the match. He appeared again on iMPACT! the next week. While working with TNA he also worked with Dale Oliver to re-record Kurt Angle's entrance music into the hip hop theme "Gold Medal", which Angle would use for the remainder of his time with the promotion.  In 2008, he released his first solo debut album Inferiority Complex . East Coast Avengers In August 2008, Tha Trademarc collaborated with Massachusetts rappers Esoteric and DC The Midi Alien to create the East Coast Avengers. Their group debut album Prison Planet was released in late 2008. The group released their song "Kill Bill O'Reilly" which caused a media controversy due to lyrics that centered on violently killing Bill O'Reilly . Michelle Malkin 's criticism of the song led to the group recording "Dear Michelle" in response. They have since released another single titled "Hey America!" Discography With John Cena You Can't See Me (May 10, 2005) For TNA Gold Medal (Kurt Angle‚Äôs Theme) (2007) Solo Inferiority Complex (April 4, 2008) Black Ash Days With DC the Midi Alien (May 16, 2015) Blood Meridian With Filthy Animals (November 22, 2019) With East Coast Avengers Prison Planet (October 7, 2008) Avengers Airwaves References External links Tha Trademarc (Marc Predka) at IMDb

, Stephanie Music Publishing, Cherry Lane Music Publishing Company, WWE and John Cena. The group alleged that Cena and the WWE stole parts of their song "Ante Up" for his theme song, arguing that the song was unlawfully sampled and clearly repeated three times, during the introduction, the second and third chorus. M.O.P. sought the destruction of the song and $150,000 in damages. They dropped the lawsuit two months later. References External links John Cena's WWE Profile John Cena's Official Entrance Video

Hoodlum: Music Inspired By the Motion Picture is the soundtrack to Bill Duke 's 1997 crime drama film Hoodlum . It was released on August 12, 1997 via Loud Records and Interscope Records , and consisted of a blend of hip hop and R&B music. The album features songs performed by 112 , Adriana Evans , Big Boi , Big Bub, Big Noyd , Chico DeBarge , Cool Breeze , Davina , Erykah Badu , Faith Evans , L.V. , Mobb Deep , Rahsaan Patterson , Rakim , Tony Rich and Wu-Tang Clan . The soundtrack peaked at number 94 on the Billboard 200 and at number 23 on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart in the United States. Mobb Deep 's single " Hoodlum " reached number 29 on the Hot Rap Songs chart. Track listing Notes "Dirty the Moocher" embodies portions of " Minnie the Moocher "; written by Cab Calloway , Clarence Gaskill , and Irving Mills ; as performed by Cab Calloway . Score A second soundtrack, featuring Elmer Bernstein 's score for the film, was issued by RCA Victor Red Seal / BMG Classics at the time of the film's release. The score was recorded in London by the Royal Philharmonic Orchestra , conducted by the composer. The album was produced by the composer's daughter, Emilie A. Bernstein (who also orchestrated the score). Track listing Charts References External links Hoodlum - Music Inspired By The Motion Picture at Discogs (list of releases)

10th Anniversary: Rap-A-Lot Records is a compilation album released by Rap-a-Lot Records to celebrate the label's tenth anniversary. The compilation contained 11 hits from the likes of the Geto Boys , Scarface and the 5th Ward Boyz , as well as two previously unreleased songs ("Sunshine" by Scarface and "Don't Give No..." by Do or Die ). Former 1 of the Girls member, Nina Creque, daughter of jazz musician Neal Creque , is featured on the previously unreleased "Sunshine" by Scarface. 10 Anniversary peaked at 48 on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums . Track listing Charts References v t e v t e

Many of Korn's first works are based on early experiences. The song " Daddy " was described by lead singer Jonathan Davis : "When I was a kid, I was being abused by somebody else and I went to my parents and told them about it, and they thought I was lying and joking around. They never did shit about it. They didn't believe it was happening to their son.... I don't really like to talk about that song. This is as much as I've ever talked about it..." "Kill You" was written about Davis's experiences as a child with his stepmother. Follow the Leader marked the first album where the majority of the lyrics did not have origins relating to early occurrences, with songs like "Justin" and "Pretty" written about incidents occurring during adulthood. Influences A few years before establishing Korn, James "Munky" Shaffer; Reginald "Fieldy" Arvizu; and David Silveria (who were three members of the funk metal band L.A.P.D. ), alongside friend Brian "Head" Welch, all had the common influences of Red Hot Chili Peppers and especially the Faith No More album The Real Thing . Likewise, Davis was greatly inspired by the adventurousness of The Real Thing upon its 1989 release: "It showed everybody you could do heavy music and not be 'metal'. It was something completely different." In the Guitar World section "The Album that Changed My Life" of January 1997, Welch listed The Real Thing by Faith No More as the album that changed his life, while Arvizu named both the Red Hot Chili Peppers' Freaky Styley and Faith No More's Introduce Yourself . Fieldy's biggest bass influences were Flea from Red Hot Chili Peppers and Les Claypool from Primus . He was also greatly inspired by Billy Gould 's chemistry with his Faith No More bandmates and Stanley Clarke . In 2015, asked about what record has stuck with him through the years, Munky first named 1992's Angel Dust by Faith No More, followed by Evil Empire by Rage Against the Machine and The Fragile by Nine Inch Nails . For his part, David Silveria named Mike Bordin of Faith No More one of his biggest influences. Munky later acknowledged the song structures and instrumentations of Faith No More in inspiring Korn's future songwriting: "Faith No More steered us in the direction where we ultimately ended up." They became "fanatics" of Faith No More singer Mike Patton , researched about him, and traveled to the band's hometown of San Francisco in order to watch them play. In this way, they discovered Patton's avant-garde metal band Mr. Bungle , whose 1991 self-titled album had a long-standing impact on Korn's experimentation, dissonance, and eccentric stylings. A notable example of Bungle's influence has been what Korn dubbed the "Mr.

The Path of Totality debuted and peaked at number ten on the Billboard 200 with 55,000 copies scanned. " Get Up! " was premiered as the lead single via Spin in April 2011. The single managed to peak at number eight on the Bubbling Under Hot 100 chart. It eventually became their first single to be certified gold in the United States. The second single, " Narcissistic Cannibal ", was released in October 2011, with its music video being directed and produced by Alexander Bulkley of ShadowMachine Films . After a stint of festival appearances, Korn promoted The Path of Totality during a headlining tour of the same name . Korn split their show into three sections. The band kicked off by playing tracks from their first two albums, including the B-side "Proud", which was originally included on the soundtrack to the 1997 film I Know What You Did Last Summer . They followed with a different stage set up, playing several of their new songs. The set list ended with hit singles and an encore. Other appearances came from Datsik , Downlink, and Dope D.O.D. A special album release performance filmed and recorded at the Hollywood Palladium was issued in various formats through Shout! Factory in September 2012. The Path of Totality won Album of the Year at the 2012 Revolver Golden Gods Awards. This was Korn's first victory at the Golden Gods Awards, a ceremony that celebrates the best in hard rock and heavy metal music. Korn was also inducted into the Kerrang! Hall of Fame during the 2011 Kerrang! Awards . On May 5, 2012, guitarist Brian "Head" Welch joined Korn on stage at the Carolina Rebellion festival to play "Blind" for the first time since his departure. As recalled in the documentary DVD Reconciliation , Welch's appearance was a spur-of-the-moment decision: Welch initially visited the festival because of his daughter, who was a fan of bands performing. Welch joined Red on stage for a song, and would eventually be persuaded to join his old bandmates in Korn for a meet and greet . Upon Korn preparing for the show, the guitar tech prepared an extra guitar and amplifier for Welch, "just in case". On July 18, 2012, Jonathan Davis told Billboard.com that Korn was getting ready to start recording their eleventh studio album that would be released independently. It was also announced that their next album would not contain any dubstep influences like The Path of Totality . Guitarist James "Munky" Shaffer stated in an interview with the Phoenix New Times that the new album would be heavier, with more aggressive "in-your-face" guitars and vocals. He went on to say that he would be using new recording techniques in the studio to give his riffs a fresh approach. In November 2012, Mudvayne bassist Ryan Martinie

on hambone rhymes. The first line of his song "Hey Bo Diddley" is derived from the nursery rhyme " Old MacDonald ". The song "Who Do You Love?" with its rap -style boasting, and his use of the African-American game known as " the dozens " on the songs "Say Man" and "Say Man, Back Again," are cited as progenitors of hip-hop music; for example, in the dialogue of the song, "Say Man", percussionist Jerome Green says the lines: "You've got the nerve to call somebody ugly. Why, you so ugly that the stork that brought you in the world oughta be arrested." Discography I used to get mad about people recording my things; now I got a new thing going ... I don't get mad about them recording my material because they keep me alive. and Radiohead while making almost every other current band seem tiny." Muse released their fourth live album, Live at Rome Olympic Stadium , on 29 November 2013 on CD/DVD and CD/Blu-ray formats. In November 2013, the film had theatrical screenings in 20 cities worldwide. The album contains the band's performance at Rome 's Stadio Olimpico on 6 July 2013, in front of over 60,000 people; it was the first concert filmed in 4K format. The concert was a part of the Unsustainable Tour, Muse's mid-2013 tour of Europe. 2014‚Äì2021: Drones and Simulation Theory Muse on stage at the O 2 Arena in London in April 2016 as part of the Drones World Tour Muse began writing their seventh album soon after the Rome concert. The band felt that the electronic side of their music was becoming too dominant, and wanted to return to a simpler rock sound. After self-producing their previous two albums, the band hired producer Robert John "Mutt" Lange so they could focus on performance and spend less time mixing and reviewing takes. Recording took place in the Vancouver Warehouse Studio from October 2014 to April 2015. Muse announced their seventh album, Drones , on 11 March 2015. The following day, they released a lyric video for " Psycho " on their YouTube channel, and made the song available for instant download with the album pre-order. Another single, " Dead Inside ", was released on 23 March. From 15 March to 16 May, Muse embarked on a short tour in small venues throughout the UK and the US, the Psycho Tour. Live performances of new songs from these concerts are included on the DVD accompanying the album along with bonus studio footage. On 18 May 2015, Muse released a lyric video for "Mercy" on their YouTube channel, and made the song available for instant download with the album pre-order. Drones was released on 8 June 2015. A concept album about the dehumanisation of modern warfare, it returned to a simpler rock sound with less elaborate production and genre experimentation. It topped the album charts in the UK, the US, Australia and most major markets. Muse headlined Lollapalooza Berlin on 13 September 2015. On 15 February 2016, Drones won the Grammy Award for Best Rock Album at the 58th Grammy Awards . On 24 June, Muse headlined the Glastonbury Festival for a third time, becoming the first act to have headlined each day of the festival (Friday, Saturday and Sunday). On 30 November 2016, Muse were announced to headline Reading and Leeds 2017. In 2017, Muse toured North America, supported by Thirty Seconds to Mars and PVRIS . On 18 May, they released " Dig Down ", the

Miles Dewey Davis III (May 26, 1926 ‚Äì September 28, 1991) was an American trumpeter, bandleader and composer. He is among the most influential and acclaimed figures in the history of jazz and 20th-century music . In a career spanning nearly five decades, Davis was at the forefront of several major stylistic developments in jazz, including‚Äîbut not limited to‚Äî bebop , cool jazz , hard bop , third stream , modal jazz , avant-garde jazz , and jazz fusion . Davis's legacy extends beyond jazz into the realms of rock , funk , classical , and hip-hop . Born into an upper-middle-class family in Alton, Illinois , and raised in East St. Louis , Davis started on the trumpet in his early teens. He left to study at Juilliard in New York City, before dropping out and making his professional debut as a member of saxophonist Charlie Parker 's bebop quintet from 1944 to 1948. Shortly afterwards, he recorded the Birth of the Cool sessions for Capitol Records , which were instrumental to the development of cool jazz. In the early 1950s, while addicted to heroin, Davis recorded some of the earliest hard bop music under Prestige Records . After a widely acclaimed comeback performance at the Newport Jazz Festival , he signed a long-term contract with Columbia Records , and recorded the album 'Round About Midnight in 1955. It was his first work with saxophonist John Coltrane and bassist Paul Chambers , key members of the sextet he led into the early 1960s. During this period, he alternated between orchestral jazz collaborations with arranger Gil Evans , such as the Spanish music ‚Äìinfluenced Sketches of Spain (1960), and band recordings, such as Milestones (1958) and Kind of Blue (1959). The latter recording remains one of the most popular jazz albums of all time, having sold over five million copies in the U.S. Davis made several lineup changes while recording Someday My Prince Will Come (1961), his 1961 Blackhawk concerts , and Seven Steps to Heaven (1963), another commercial success that introduced bassist Ron Carter , pianist Herbie Hancock and drummer Tony Williams . After adding saxophonist Wayne Shorter to his new quintet in 1964, Davis led them on a series of more abstract recordings often composed by the band members, helping pioneer the post-bop genre with albums such as E.S.P. (1965) and Miles Smiles (1967), before transitioning into his electric period. During the 1970s, he experimented with rock, funk, African rhythms , emerging electronic music technology , and an ever-changing lineup of musicians, including keyboardist Joe Zawinul , drummer Al Foster , bassist Michael Henderson and guitarist John McLaughlin . This period, beginning with Davis's 1969 studio album In a

of jazz music". It passed with a vote of 409‚Äì0 on December 15, 2009. The trumpet Davis used on the recording is displayed on the campus of the University of North Carolina at Greensboro . It was donated to the school by Arthur "Buddy" Gist, who met Davis in 1949 and became a close friend. The gift was the reason why the jazz program at UNCG is named the Miles Davis Jazz Studies Program. In 1986, the New England Conservatory awarded Davis an honorary doctorate for his contributions to music. Since 1960, the National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences (NARAS) honored him with eight Grammy Awards, a Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award and three Grammy Hall of Fame Awards. In 2001, The Miles Davis Story , a two-hour documentary film by Mike Dibb , won an International Emmy Award for arts documentary of the year. Since 2005, the Miles Davis Jazz Committee has held an annual Miles Davis Jazz Festival. Also in 2005, the Davis biography, The Last Miles was published, and a London exhibition was held of his paintings, The Last Miles: The Music of Miles Davis, 1980‚Äì1991 , was released detailing his final years and eight of his albums from the 1960s and 1970s were reissued in celebration of the 50th anniversary of his signing to Columbia Records. In 2006, Davis was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. In 2012, the U.S. Postal Service issued commemorative stamps featuring Davis. Miles Ahead was a 2015 American music film directed by Don Cheadle , co-written by Cheadle with Steven Baigelman , Stephen J. Rivele and Christopher Wilkinson , which interprets the life and compositions of Davis. It premiered at the New York Film Festival in October 2015. The film stars Cheadle, Emayatzy Corinealdi as Frances Taylor, Ewan McGregor , Michael Stuhlbarg and Lakeith Stanfield . That same year a statue of him was erected in his home city, Alton, Illinois , and listeners of BBC Radio and Jazz FM voted Davis the greatest jazz musician. Publications such as The Guardian have also ranked Davis among the best of all jazz musicians. In 2018, American rapper Q-Tip played Miles Davis in a theater production titled My Funny Valentine . Q-Tip had previously played Davis in 2010. In 2019, the documentary Miles Davis: Birth of the Cool , directed by Stanley Nelson , premiered at the Sundance Film Festival . It was later released on PBS ' American Masters series. Davis is the subject of the upcoming period romance film Davis & Juliette about his meeting Juliette Gr√©co in Paris in 1949. In a statement to accompany the film's announcement, English musician and co-producer Mick Jagger regarded Davis as "inarguably

communities.summary:
**Title**: Trademarc's Music Career

**Summary**:  
Marc "Trademarc" Predka gained fame through his 2005 collaboration with cousin John Cena on the album *You Can't See Me*, co-writing and featuring in its singles and videos. He later contributed to TNA wrestling by re-recording Kurt Angle‚Äôs entrance theme and participated in an on-screen storyline. In 2008 he launched a solo career with *Inferiority Complex*, then formed the East Coast Avengers, whose protest song "Kill Bill O'Reilly" sparked media controversy and a follow-up track "Dear Michelle." Predka has continued releasing solo and collaborative projects, including *Black Ash Days* and *Blood Meridian*.

**Keywords**: Trademarc, John Cena, East Coast Avengers, You Can't See Me, Kill Bill O'Reilly

**Title**: John Cena‚Äôs Entrance Theme

**Summary**:  
‚ÄúThe Time Is Now‚Äù is John Cena‚Äôs best-known entrance theme, used in WWE from 2005 through his 2025 retirement match. Recorded with his cousin Marc ‚ÄúTrademarc‚Äù Predka and producer Jake One, the track samples M.O.P.‚Äôs ‚ÄúAnte Up,‚Äù prompting a short-lived 2008 lawsuit that was later dropped. Released as the lead single from Cena‚Äôs debut album *You Can‚Äôt See Me*, the song also became an Internet meme and anchors Cena‚Äôs rapper-turned-superstar persona that evolved from early-2000s freestyle segments on *SmackDown*.

**Keywords**:  
John Cena, WWE entrance theme, The Time Is Now, You Can‚Äôt See Me, Ante Up sampling

**Title**: Prince‚Äôs Emancipation Album

**Summary**:  
Prince‚Äôs 19th studio album ‚ÄúEmancipation‚Äù is a 36-track, triple-disc set released on 19 Nov 1996 by NPG/EMI to celebrate his freedom from Warner Bros. after 18 conflict-filled years. The album‚Äîexactly 60 minutes per disc‚Äîbreaks new ground for Prince by including four outside covers and extensive sampling from funk/hip-hop classics, while every printed ‚ÄúI‚Äù is replaced with a stylized ‚ÄúüëÅ‚Äù symbol. Despite modest U.S. sales (~500 k copies), its 3-disc format earned double-platinum certification and the subsequent Jam of the Year Tour re-energized his career.

**Keywords**:  
Emancipation, Prince, triple album, Warner Bros., üëÅ symbol

**Title**: Rap-A-Lot 10th Anniversary Compilation

**Summary**:  
"10th Anniversary: Rap-A-Lot Records" is a 1996 compilation album commemorating a decade of the Houston-based hip-hop label. It assembles 11 of the imprint‚Äôs signature tracks from flagship acts such as the Geto Boys, Scarface and 5th Ward Boyz, augmented by two exclusive new cuts‚ÄîScarface‚Äôs "Sunshine" (featuring jazz vocalist Nina Creque) and Do or Die‚Äôs "Don‚Äôt Give No...". The collection reached No. 48 on Billboard‚Äôs Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums chart, underscoring Rap-A-Lot‚Äôs enduring Southern rap influence.

**Keywords**: Rap-A-Lot Records, 10th anniversary compilation, Geto Boys, Scarface, Southern hip-hop

**Title**: Hoodlum Soundtrack Overview  

**Summary**:  
The Hoodlum soundtrack, released 12 Aug 1997 on Loud/Interscope, compiles hip-hop and R&B tracks from artists such as Mobb Deep, Erykah Badu, Rakim, Wu-Tang Clan and Faith Evans, peaking at #94 on the Billboard 200 and #23 on the Top R&B/Hip-Hop Albums; Mobb Deep‚Äôs single ‚ÄúHoodlum‚Äù hit #29 on the Hot Rap Songs chart. A separate RCA Victor disc features Elmer Bernstein‚Äôs orchestral score recorded by the Royal Philharmonic in London and produced by the composer‚Äôs daughter, Emilie A. Bernstein.  

**Keywords**: Hoodlum soundtrack, Mobb Deep, Elmer Bernstein, 1997 hip-hop/R&B, Royal Philharmonic

**Title**: Brady Seals Debut Album  

**Summary**:  
‚ÄúThe Truth‚Äù is country artist Brady Seals‚Äô first solo album after departing the band Little Texas, released on Reprise Records in February 1997. The project produced three singles‚Äî‚ÄúAnother You, Another Me,‚Äù ‚ÄúStill Standing Tall,‚Äù and ‚ÄúNatural Born Lovers‚Äù‚Äîwith only the first reaching the Top 40 on Hot Country Songs. Seals co-produced the record with Rodney Crowell, assembling a roster of Nashville A-list musicians and technical staff that lend polished instrumentation and rich arrangements across the track list.

**Keywords**:  
Brady Seals, The Truth album, country music debut, Reprise Records, Hot Country Songs

**Title**: Incubus Album & Tour Cycles 2009-2015  

**Summary**:  
Between 2009 and 2015, Incubus released the albums *Monuments and Melodies*, *If Not Now, When?*, and the *Trust Fall (Side A)* EP, each supported by extensive global touring. The band experimented with orchestral elements, fan-interactive projects like *Incubus HQ Live*, and co-headlining runs with Linkin Park and Deftones. They consistently debuted new material live‚Äîe.g., ‚ÄúTrust Fall‚Äù at KROQ‚Äôs Almost Acoustic Christmas 2014‚Äîwhile navigating lineup stability and maintaining their signature fusion of alt-metal, funk, and hip-hop.  

**Keywords**:  
Incubus, If Not Now When, Trust Fall EP, 2011-2015 tours, alt-metal evolution

**Title:** Ghost Rider Song Covers

**Summary:**  
The protopunk band Suicide‚Äôs 1977 debut album introduced ‚ÄúGhost Rider,‚Äù a track inspired by the Marvel Comics anti-hero. Over four decades the song has become an underground staple, repeatedly reinterpreted across genres and countries. Notable versions span Danish punk (Sods, 1979), synth-pop (Soft Cell, 1983), hardcore (Henry Rollins, 1987 & 1994), alternative rock (R.E.M., 1988; The Gories, 1990), industrial (The Young Gods, 2008), hip-hop (M.I.A. sample, 2010), and Japanese alt-rock (The Novembers, 2019). These covers, live renditions, and samples illustrate the song‚Äôs enduring influence on punk, electronic, and experimental scenes worldwide.

**Keywords:** Suicide, Ghost Rider, cover versions, punk legacy, cross-genre influence

**Title**: Bo Diddley‚Äôs Legacy  

**Summary**:  
Bo Diddley (born Ellas Bates McDaniel) was a pioneering guitarist, singer, and songwriter who fused African rhythms with blues to create the signature ‚ÄúBo Diddley beat,‚Äù a cornerstone of rock, pop, and hip-hop. After moving from Mississippi to Chicago, he absorbed sanctified church rhythms and street-corner blues, launching his career with the 1955 hit ‚ÄúBo Diddley.‚Äù Known for his rectangular guitars and innovative use of tremolo and reverb, he recorded prolifically for Chess/Checker, toured internationally, and influenced artists from the Beatles to the Clash. Inducted into multiple Halls of Fame, he also produced early Marvin Gaye sessions and remained a crossover live favorite through the 1960s surf era.  

**Keywords**: Bo Diddley beat, rock-and-roll pioneer, Chess Records, African rhythms, guitar innovator

**Title**: Faith No More Band History

**Summary**: Faith No More, formed in 1979 in San Francisco, evolved from Sharp Young Men through Faith No Man before adopting its final name in 1983. Core members Billy Gould, Mike Bordin, and Roddy Bottum anchored a rotating lineup that stabilized with Mike Patton‚Äôs 1988 arrival, yielding the multi-platinum Grammy-nominated album *The Real Thing* and its hit ‚ÄúEpic.‚Äù The band‚Äôs genre-blending style‚Äîfusing metal, funk, hip-hop, and experimental rock‚Äîpeaked with *Angel Dust* (1992) and influenced nu-metal acts like Korn and Limp Bizkit. After breakups, reunions, and the 2015 album *Sol Invictus*, touring plans were halted by COVID-19 and Patton‚Äôs health issues, leaving the group inactive.

**Keywords**: alternative metal, Mike Patton, The Real Thing, nu-metal pioneers, San Francisco rock

**Title**: Miles Davis Agharta Era  

**Summary**:  
In the mid-1970s, Miles Davis pushed jazz into abrasive electric-funk territory, alienating traditionalists while captivating younger rock crowds. Recorded live in Osaka on 1 Feb 1975, the double album *Agharta* captures his septet‚Äîanchored by Henderson, Foster, Lucas, Mtume and sparked by Cosey‚Äôs effects-laden guitar and Fortune‚Äôs sax‚Äîstretching grooves into dark, cathartic improvisations under Davis‚Äô gestural direction. Released in Japan that August, the album‚Äôs mythic artwork and uncompromising sound were met with critical scorn, yet later generations hailed it as the apex of Davis‚Äô electric period and a foundational text for experimental rock, hip-hop and Afrofuturist art.  

**Keywords**:  
Agharta, electric fusion, Pete Cosey, 1975 Japan tour, Afrofuturism

**Title**: "Let Me Know" Song Disambiguation

**Summary**:  
The phrase "Let Me Know" is the title of numerous songs by a wide range of artists spanning multiple decades and genres, from Gloria Gaynor‚Äôs 1979 track to recent releases by K-pop group STAYC and alt-pop band LANY. The shared title appears across pop, R&B, electronic, and hip-hop catalogs, including works by Janet Jackson, BTS, Juice Wrld, Perfume, and Collie Buddz. Because these identically titled songs are otherwise unrelated, they are collected on a disambiguation page to help readers locate the specific track or article they seek.

**Keywords**:  
Let Me Know, song disambiguation, multiple artists, shared title, music index

**Title**: CeCe Peniston‚Äôs ‚ÄúNobody Else‚Äù

**Summary**:  
‚ÄúNobody Else‚Äù is a 1998 house-infused single by CeCe Peniston, intended as the flagship track for an ultimately shelved Silk Entertainment album. Co-written and produced by Steve ‚ÄúSilk‚Äù Hurley, the song blends gospel and soul with club-ready mixes, earning Hurley a Grammy nomination for Best Non-Classical Remixed Recording. Despite the album‚Äôs cancellation, the single thrived internationally, appearing on the Italian compilation *Hit Mania Dance Estate 1998, Vol. 2* and peaking at #2 on Italy‚Äôs album chart. Multiple remixes across vinyl and CD formats sustained its club and radio presence.

**Keywords**:  
CeCe Peniston, Steve Hurley, house remixes, Grammy nomination, 1998 dance single

**Title**: J. Cole‚Äôs Rise to Prominence

**Summary**: Between 2010 and 2012, J. Cole transitioned from mixtape acclaim to major-label stardom, highlighted by his Roc Nation signing and the breakout success of *Friday Night Lights*. He built momentum with high-profile guest spots, singles like ‚ÄúWork Out,‚Äù and the chart-topping debut album *Cole World: The Sideline Story*. Strategic collaborations with Drake, Kendrick Lamar, and Trey Songz, plus relentless touring and weekly free releases, cemented his reputation as a leading new voice in hip-hop.

**Keywords**: J. Cole, Friday Night Lights, Cole World, Roc Nation, Work Out

**Title**: J. Cole Career & Ventures Overview

**Summary**:  
J. Cole is a Grammy-winning rapper, producer, and entrepreneur whose discography spans introspective, socially conscious albums like *2014 Forest Hills Drive* and *KOD*. Beyond music, he founded Dreamville Records and the Dreamville Foundation, channeling profits and influence into artist development and Fayetteville, NC community programs. Cole‚Äôs business portfolio includes minority ownership in Tidal and a Puma sneaker collaboration, while his personal life‚Äîmarried to college sweetheart Melissa Heholt and father of two‚Äîremains largely private. Public feuds with Lil Pump and Noname have highlighted his role as a generational commentator, reinforcing his stance on authenticity and activism within hip-hop.

**Keywords**:  
Dreamville, discography, Tidal, philanthropy, hip-hop activism

**Title**: Miles Davis's Electric-Funk Evolution  

**Summary**:  
Between 1970-1975 Miles Davis aggressively fused jazz with rock, funk and avant-garde electronics, weathering accusations of ‚Äúselling out‚Äù while courting young Black and rock audiences. Landmark albums‚Äî*Bitches Brew*, *Jack Johnson*, *On the Corner*, *Get Up with It*‚Äîand marathon live sets at the Fillmores, Isle of Wight and Osaka document a rotating cast (Corea, Jarrett, Henderson, Cosey, Mtume) shifting from improvisatory jazz-rock to dense, groove-based ‚Äúspace music‚Äù shaped by Stockhausen‚Äôs influence. Despite chart-topping jazz success, Columbia‚Äôs pop marketing frustrated Davis, while deteriorating health, substance abuse and critical hostility culminated in a five-year retirement after the 1975 Japanese tour.  

**Keywords**:  
electric period, funk-jazz fusion, Bitches Brew, Stockhausen influence, 1970s hiatus

**Title**: Brady Seals Career Overview

**Summary**: Brady Seals is an American country music artist who began his career in 1988 as co-lead vocalist and keyboardist for the band Little Texas, contributing to all their major hits until 1994. After departing Little Texas, he launched a solo career, releasing three studio albums between 1996 and 2003, including his only solo Top 40 hit "Another You, Another Me." In 2002, he formed the quartet Hot Apple Pie, which charted three singles including "Hillbillies," and released his fourth solo album "Play Time" in 2009. Raised in a musical family in Fairfield, Ohio, Seals started playing piano at age nine and comes from a family of notable musicians including cousins Jim Seals and Dan Seals.

**Keywords**: country music, Little Texas, solo artist, Hot Apple Pie, musician

**Title**: Bo Diddley 1958 Debut Album

**Summary**: Bo Diddley‚Äôs self-titled 1958 debut album compiles his groundbreaking 1955-1958 singles that introduced the iconic ‚ÄúBo Diddley beat,‚Äù cementing his place in rock & roll history. Released by Chess Records, the 12-track LP was later paired with 1959‚Äôs *Go Bo Diddley* on Rolling Stone‚Äôs 500 Greatest Albums list, peaking at #216 in 2012 before slipping to #455 in 2020. Critics laud the record as essential listening; AllMusic awarded it five stars, and in 2022 it was inducted into the Blues Hall of Fame as a ‚ÄòClassic of Blues Recording ‚Äì Album‚Äô.

**Keywords**: Bo Diddley beat, Chess Records, Rolling Stone 500, Blues Hall of Fame, rock & roll essential

**Title**: Miles Davis at Fillmore West  

**Summary**:  
Black Beauty: Miles Davis at Fillmore West captures the trumpeter‚Äôs April 10, 1970 concert‚Äîhis second night opening for the Grateful Dead‚Äîmarking a deliberate pivot from jazz clubs to rock venues to promote Bitches Brew. Davis led a septet through a single, unbroken suite, using coded trumpet phrases to cue seamless shifts between old staples and new electric pieces, creating an improvisational jazz-rock hybrid. The performance won over a hall of initially indifferent hippies, expanded Davis‚Äô counter-culture audience, and was documented on a Japan-only 1973 double LP that finally saw U.S. release in 1997. Critics praised the audacious fusion energy but split over sound quality, Steve Grossman‚Äôs sax work, and the risks of an entirely improvised set.  

**Keywords**:  
Fillmore West, Bitches Brew era, jazz-rock fusion, live improvisation, trumpet cues

**Title**: Faith No More‚Äôs Break-Up & Reunion  

**Summary**:  
After the 1997 release of *Album of the Year*, internal tensions and side-project ambitions fueled rumors of Faith No More‚Äôs demise, culminating in an April 1998 statement that the band had mutually agreed to split following their final Lisbon show. An 11-year hiatus ended in 2009 when the *Album of the Year* lineup reunited for The Second Coming Tour, headlining major European and Australian festivals and adding contemporary covers to their set. Activity continued sporadically‚Äî2011 South-American dates, 2012 festival circuit‚Äîuntil the band confirmed they were writing new material, culminating in the 2015 album *Sol Invictus* and another hiatus by 2018.  

**Keywords**: reunion, hiatus, *Sol Invictus*, *Album of the Year*, Second Coming Tour

**Title**: Miles Davis's Evolution and Legacy

**Summary**:  
Miles Davis was a transformative force in jazz, pioneering multiple genres from bebop to jazz fusion. His career spanned nearly five decades, marked by constant reinvention and experimentation with rock, funk, and electronic music. After a controversial electric period in the 1970s and a health-induced hiatus, Davis returned in the 1980s with pop-infused albums that achieved commercial success despite critical skepticism. His influence extended beyond music into visual arts and culture, cementing his legacy as one of the most innovative and respected figures in 20th-century music.

**Keywords**:  
Miles Davis, jazz fusion, musical innovation, electric period, cultural legacy

**Title**: Muse 2010-2017 Era

**Summary**: Between 2010 and 2017, Muse evolved from grand symphonic rock to electronic experimentation before returning to stripped-down rock. After the orchestral *The Resistance* (2009) earned them a Grammy and global festival headlines, 2012‚Äôs dubstep-tinged *The 2nd Law* spawned Olympic anthem ‚ÄúSurvival‚Äù and stadium hits like ‚ÄúMadness.‚Äù They headlined Glastonbury, Reading/Leeds, Lollapalooza and released the 4K-concert film *Live at Rome Olympic Stadium*. 2015‚Äôs concept album *Drones* abandoned electronics for raw rock, debuted at #1 worldwide, won Best Rock Album at the 58th Grammys, and sent them on the Drones World Tour.

**Keywords**: Muse, The 2nd Law, Drones, Grammy winners, stadium tours

**Title**: Birth of the Cool Era  

**Summary**:  
Between 1944 and 1950, Miles Davis transitioned from Juilliard student to bebop sideman, ultimately forming the nine-piece Miles Davis Nonet whose 1948-50 Capitol recordings became the 1957 compilation *Birth of the Cool*. Rejecting bebop‚Äôs virtuosic excess, Davis, Gil Evans, Gerry Mulligan and John Lewis crafted a relaxed, chamber-like sound featuring French horn and tuba that foreshadowed West-Coast ‚Äúcool‚Äù jazz. Despite poor initial sales, the Nonet‚Äôs singles and Davis‚Äôs 1949 Paris festival debut cemented his reputation as an innovator.  

**Keywords**:  
Miles Davis Nonet, Birth of the Cool, cool jazz, Gil Evans, 52nd Street

**Title**: Korn‚Äôs 2010s Album Cycle & Lineup Changes  

**Summary**:  
The chunks chronicle Korn‚Äôs creative and personnel shifts from 2010-2016, centering on three albums‚Äî*Korn III: Remember Who You Are*, the dubstep-infused *The Path of Totality*, and the return-to-form *The Paradigm Shift*. After Roadrunner releases, the band embraced EDM collaborations (*Totality*), scored a gold single with ‚ÄúGet Up!‚Äù, and won Revolver‚Äôs Album of the Year. Guitarist Brian ‚ÄúHead‚Äù Welch‚Äôs permanent reunion, temporary bassist Ryan Martinie, and producer Nick Raskulinecz framed the 2013 comeback record *The Paradigm Shift*, supported by the single ‚ÄúNever Never‚Äù and a revived Family Values Tour. Subsequent years saw *The Serenity of Suffering* (2016) featuring Corey Taylor, reinforcing Korn‚Äôs heavier direction.  

**Keywords**:  
Korn albums 2010s, Brian Welch return, The Path of Totality, The Paradigm Shift, The Serenity of Suffering

**Title**: Miles Davis's 1950s Evolution

**Summary**:  
During the 1950s, Miles Davis overcame heroin addiction, rebuilt his career, and pioneered hard bop and modal jazz. After kicking drugs in 1954, he formed his first classic quintet, signed with Columbia, and produced landmark Prestige sessions later released as *Cookin‚Äô*, *Relaxin‚Äô*, *Workin‚Äô*, and *Steamin‚Äô*. His muted trumpet sound, spacious phrasing, and shift away from bebop culminated in the 1959 masterpiece *Kind of Blue*, which introduced modal jazz to a mass audience and became one of the best-selling jazz albums ever.

**Keywords**:  
hard bop, modal jazz, Kind of Blue, first quintet, heroin recovery

**Title**: Go Bo Diddley Album

**Summary**: *Go Bo Diddley* is Bo Diddley‚Äôs second studio album, released in July 1959 on Checker Records, notable for being his first LP to include previously unreleased material. The album compiles several 1958-59 singles‚Äîsuch as ‚ÄúI‚Äôm Sorry,‚Äù ‚ÄúCrackin‚Äô Up,‚Äù and the crossover hit ‚ÄúSay Man‚Äù‚Äîalongside four album-only tracks. Recorded in mono with an Ampex-350, it features core collaborators Peggy Jones, Jerome Green, Willie Dixon, and others, and was later ranked among Rolling Stone‚Äôs 500 Greatest Albums of All Time.

**Keywords**: Bo Diddley, Checker Records, 1959, Say Man, Greatest Albums

**Title**: Muse 2006-2009 Touring & Albums

**Summary**: Between 2006 and 2009, Muse promoted their fourth studio album *Black Holes and Revelations* with an extensive world tour that spanned Europe, North America, Asia, and Oceania, highlighted by headline slots at Reading/Leeds 2006 and a record-setting sold-out Wembley Stadium in June 2007. The concerts produced the live release *HAARP* (2008), later named one of NME‚Äôs greatest live albums. After winning Best British Live Act at the 2007 Brit Awards, the band continued global festival appearances‚Äîincluding Austin City Limits, Vegoose, Rock in Rio Lisboa, and V Festival‚Äîwhile releasing successful singles like ‚ÄúSupermassive Black Hole,‚Äù ‚ÄúStarlight,‚Äù and ‚ÄúKnights of Cydonia.‚Äù Their 2009 follow-up album, *The Resistance*, became a chart-topper in 19 countries and marked their first self-produced record, despite bassist Chris Wolstenholme‚Äôs brief rehab stint for alcoholism.

**Keywords**: Muse, Black Holes and Revelations, HAARP, Wembley 2007, The Resistance

**Title**: Miles Davis's Final Years and Legacy

**Summary**:  
In his later life, Miles Davis distanced himself from his iconic early works like *Kind of Blue*, rejecting nostalgia and embracing electronic and experimental sounds. Despite health struggles, including diabetes and respiratory issues, he remained active, releasing albums like *Tutu* and *Doo-Bop*, and performing until shortly before his death in 1991. His personal life was marked by tumultuous relationships and violence, culminating in a quiet death in California. Davis‚Äôs estate, valued at over $1 million, was divided among select family members, excluding two of his sons. His legacy remains polarizing, with critics divided over his post-1975 output, yet he was honored with Grammy and lifetime achievement awards, and posthumously celebrated for his contributions to jazz and beyond.

**Keywords**:  
Miles Davis, late career, legacy, jazz evolution, final performances

**Title**: Hoodlum Film Plot & Production

**Summary**:  
The 1997 crime drama *Hoodlum* dramatizes the 1930s Harlem turf war between Black numbers-king Ellsworth ‚ÄúBumpy‚Äù Johnson and Dutch Schultz‚Äôs Italian-Jewish mafia, culminating in Johnson‚Äôs alliance with Lucky Luciano and Schultz‚Äôs assassination. Key events include poisoned ice-cream retribution, the murder of Johnson‚Äôs cousin Illinois, and a bribery deal that ends the bloodshed. Filmed in Chicago despite its Harlem setting, the movie mixed hip-hop soundtrack with period aesthetics, earning mixed reviews for historical liberties and a 43 % Rotten Tomatoes score.

**Keywords**: Hoodlum, Bumpy Johnson, Dutch Schultz, 1930s Harlem, crime drama

**Title:** Count Basie‚Äôs Legacy and Collaborations  

**Summary:**  
Count Basie, a pioneering jazz pianist and bandleader, sustained the Big Band era by collaborating with iconic vocalists such as Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Sinatra, Joe Williams, and Tony Bennett, producing landmark albums from the 1950s through the 1970s. His orchestra, noted for the ‚ÄúNew Testament‚Äù band sound, featured arrangements by Quincy Jones, Neal Hefti, and Sammy Nestico, yielding Grammy-winning and Hall-of-Fame recordings. Basie‚Äôs later life was marked by personal losses‚Äîhis wife Catherine in 1983 and his own death to pancreatic cancer in 1984‚Äîyet his influence endures through honors including the Presidential Medal of Freedom, a U.S. postage stamp, and multiple inductions into music Halls of Fame.  

**Keywords:**  
Count Basie, Big Band jazz, Ella Fitzgerald, Frank Sinatra, Grammy Hall of Fame
